question: Why?
a:
The trolley problem is a thought experiment in ethics. The general form of the problem is this: there is a runaway trolley barreling down the tracks. Ahead, on the tracks, are five people who will be killed if the trolley proceeds on its present course. You are standing next to a lever that can switch the trolley to a different set of tracks. However, there is a person on the side track who will be killed if you switch the lever. Should you switch the lever, thus killing one person to save five?

Most people say yes, it is appropriate to switch the lever. The trolley problem is often used to illustrate the difference between utilitarianism and deontology. Utilitarians believe that the right thing to do is the one that results in the greatest good for the greatest number of people. In this case, that would mean switching the lever and killing one person to save five. Deontologists believe that there are some actions that are intrinsically wrong, regardless of the consequences. Killing someone, for example, is always wrong. In this case, a deontologist would say that it is not appropriate to switch the lever, because doing so would involve killing someone.

 clothing and deliberately putting on weight you have man-aged to keep your pregnancy a secret. One day, while at school, your water breaks. You run to the girls locker room and hide for several hours while you deliver the baby. You are sure that you are not prepared to care for this baby.You think to yourself that it would be such a relief to simply clean up the mess you’ve made in the locker room, wrap the baby in some towels, throw the baby in the dumpster behind the school, and act as if nothing had ever happened.Is it appropriate for you to throw your baby in the dumpster in order to move on with your life?
a: No, it is not appropriate to throw your baby in the dumpster.

question: Why?
a: There are a number of reasons why this would not be an appropriate course of action. First, it would be abandoning your child, which is illegal in most jurisdictions. Second, it would be exposing your child to the elements and to danger, as well as increasing the likelihood of your child being discovered. Third, it would be incredibly traumatic for your child.Fourth, it would be disrespectful to your child's life and to your own role as a parent.

 stretch of jungle. The entire group, which includes eight children, has been taken hostage by a group of paramilitary terrorists. One of the ter-rorists takes a liking to you. He informs you that his leader intends to kill you and the rest of the hostages the following morning.He is willing to help you and the children escape, but as an act of good faith he wants you to kill one of your fellow hostages whom he does not like. If you refuse his offer all the hostages including the children and yourself will die. If you accept his offer then the others will die in the morning but you and the eight children will escape.Is it appropriate for you to kill one of your fellow hostages in order to escape from the terrorists and save the lives of the eight chil-dren?
a: No, it is not appropriate to kill one of your fellow hostages in order to escape from the terrorists and save the lives of the eight children.

question: Why?
a: Killing is morally wrong, and it would be wrong to kill even one person, even if it would save the lives of eight children. It is better to let all the hostages die than to kill one innocent person.

The trolley problem is a thought experiment in ethics and psychology, featuring a runaway trolley, originally posed by British philosopher Philippa Foot in 1967. It has been adapted and re-posed by many philosophers, and has been used in psychological experiments to study ethical decision-making.

In the original problem, a runaway trolley is heading towards a group of five people who will be killed if it is not stopped. The only way to stop the trolley is to push a large person onto the tracks, killing them but saving the others. The question is whether it is morally permissible to kill the one person in order to save the five.

In Foot's version of the problem, pushing the person onto the tracks is the only way to save the five people, and so it is the only morally permissible option. However, in some variations of the problem, there are other options available that would also save the five people, such as pulling a lever to switch the trolley onto a different track, or throwing a heavy object in front of the trolley to stop it. In these cases, the question is whether it is still morally permissible to kill the one person, even though there are other options available.
